questions.text: A 31-year-old man, who was hospitalized for substance-induced psychosis two days ago, has had episodic neck stiffness and pain for the past 8 hours. These episodes last for approximately 25 minutes and are accompanied by his neck rotating to the right. During the last episode, he was able to relieve the stiffness by lightly touching his jaw. He has received six doses of haloperidol for auditory hallucinations since his admission. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg. Examination shows a flexed neck rotated to the right. The neck is rigid with limited range of motion. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia manifests with painful torticollis (as seen here), opisthotonus, oculogyric crisis, trismus, tongue spasm, and/or laryngospasm. Risk factors include male sex and young age. This condition's pathophysiology is incompletely understood but an imbalance between dopaminergic activity in the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia (due to D2 receptor antagonism by the antipsychotic) and cholinergic transmission in the striatum is thought to play a role. A centrally acting anticholinergic drug such as benztropine or diphenhydramine is the first-line treatment for neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia (see “Overview of extrapyramidal symptoms” table).

The role of cholinergic transmission in the pathophysiology of neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia is also supported by the observation that the risk of acute dystonia is lower with low-potency typical antipsychotics, which have an anticholinergic effect and a weaker antidopaminergic effect when compared with high-potency typical antipsychotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy can be used as an adjunctive treatment for this patient's condition. However, highly effective, well-tolerated pharmacotherapy would be the first-line intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene is a skeletal muscle relaxant used to treat malignant hyperthermia, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, and (severe) chronic spasticity resulting from upper motor neuron damage (e.g., stroke, multiple sclerosis). Although the patient suffers from spasticity in his neck, the condition is acute and not chronic. In addition, since dantrolene may also cause psychiatric side effects (e.g., depression, confusion, insomnia), it should be given with caution in patients with a history of psychiatric symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Baclofen is a GABA receptor agonist commonly used as a muscle relaxant to treat spasticity. However, it shows little effect in the treatment of secondary dystonia (e.g., medication-induced acute dystonia) and would only be indicated after other preferred treatments have failed. Baclofen is usually used for treating primary dystonia (idiopathic, hereditary) and is more effective in children and adolescents than in adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is the first-line treatment for akathisia, which is the most common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic drugs. While this patient is at risk for akathisia, it is characterized by restlessness, fidgeting, and/or pacing. Instead, this patient's cervical muscle spasms are characteristic of another extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics.
questions.hint: The repeated episodes of painful neck stiffness are suggestive of acute dystonia, an extrapyramidal side effect that typically occurs within a few days of initiating or increasing the dose of a high-potency typical antipsychotic (e.g., haloperidol).

questions.text:
A 23-year-old primigravid woman at 8 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of increasing confusion and high-grade fever over the past 16 hours. Three days ago, she was prescribed metoclopramide by her physician for the treatment of nausea and vomiting. She has a history of depression. Current medications include fluoxetine. She is confused and not oriented to time, place, or person. Her temperature is 39.8°C (103.6°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 168/96 mm Hg. Examination shows profuse diaphoresis and flushed skin. Muscle rigidity is present. Her deep tendon reflexes are decreased bilaterally. Mental status examination shows psychomotor agitation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
17,500/mm3



Serum



 Creatinine
1.4 mg/dL


 Total bilirubin
0.7 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase
45 U/L


 AST
122 U/L


 ALT
138 U/L


 Creatine kinase
1070 U/L


Which of the following drugs is most likely to also cause the condition that is responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atropine does not cause NMS, but it may induce anticholinergic syndrome, which can, like NMS, cause tachycardia, hyperthermia with flushed skin, and confusion. However, muscle rigidity and an associated increase in CK levels are not associated with anticholinergic syndrome. Furthermore, anticholinergic syndrome does not cause diaphoresis. Instead, one of its hallmark features is dry skin due to anhidrosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Succinylcholine is not a cause of NMS. However, an important complication of succinylcholine therapy is malignant hyperthermia (MH). Clinically, MH can manifest similarly to NMS with hyperthermia, severe muscle rigidity, and autonomic instability, but the progression is typically hyperacute over minutes to hours, which is not the case in this patient. In addition, MH is usually triggered by volatile anesthetics or succinylcholine during anesthesia, which this patient has not recently undergone.

C) INCORRECT:

Phenelzine is not associated with NMS; however, if combined with foods rich in tyramine (e.g., cheese or red wine), it can result in hypertensive crisis. While this patient has elevated blood pressure, it is not in the range of hypertensive crisis (i.e., > 180/120 mm Hg), ruling out this differential diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

High-potency antipsychotics such as haloperidol are the most common cause of neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), but low-potency or atypical antipsychotics, as well as antiemetics like metoclopramide, have also been associated with NMS. While symptoms usually develop during the first 2 weeks of therapy, as seen in this patient, NMS may also develop after years of continuous therapy and without any associated increase of dose. Nonetheless, higher doses or switching antipsychotics are risk factors for the development of NMS.

The most important therapeutic measure is the discontinuation of the triggering substance. This patient should be transferred to the intensive care unit for supportive treatment including fluid resuscitation, cardiorespiratory management, and measures to lower body temperature. Administration of dopamine agonists (e.g., bromocriptine) and/or dantrolene can be considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Dextroamphetamine or other amphetamines do not cause NMS, but intoxication with these substances can manifest with similar symptoms of psychomotor agitation, hyperthermia, altered mental status, and autonomic instability. Rhabdomyolysis and transaminitis may also develop, but muscle rigidity and leukocytosis would not be expected. Also, the relatively slow progression of this patient's symptoms over the course of 16 hours suggests another diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline is not associated with NMS. It can, however, cause serotonin syndrome (SS), which shares many of the same features of NMS, including fever, diaphoresis, psychomotor agitation, and altered mental status. While this patient is taking fluoxetine, which puts her at risk of developing SS, the condition usually also manifests with gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea), and neurological findings of tremor, hyperreflexia, myoclonus, and/or ataxia, none of which this patient has. Moreover, serotonin syndrome does not cause leukocytosis.
questions.hint: This woman's clinical features of hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, bradyreflexia, altered mental status, autonomic instability (tachycardia, hypertension) in combination with laboratory studies showing leukocytosis, increased transaminases, and elevated creatine kinase, suggest neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS).

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician with involuntary lip smacking and hand and leg movements for the past two weeks. The movements are causing him difficulty walking and functioning at work. He has bipolar disorder treated with fluphenazine. Three months ago, he was hospitalized because of a manic episode, and his dosage was adjusted. Since then, he has not experienced a depressed mood, increased energy, irritability, or a change in his eating or sleeping patterns. He does not have suicidal or homicidal ideation. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 126/78 mmHg. Examination shows repetitive lip smacking and dance-like hand and leg movements. His speech is not pressured, and his affect is appropriate. He is switched from fluphenazine to risperidone and his symptoms improve. Which of the following mechanisms explains this patient's improvement?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone) have a weaker acetylcholine antagonism than typical (e.g., fluphenazine) antipsychotics. However, acetylcholine antagonism does not contribute to extrapyramidal adverse effects such as tardive dyskinesia. Common adverse effects of acetylcholine antagonism include dry mouth, increased temperature, reduced sweating, vision changes, urinary retention, and confusion.

B) INCORRECT:

Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone) may antagonize histamine receptors to a greater degree than typical antipsychotics (e.g., fluphenazine), which may contribute to adverse effects such as sedation and weight gain. However, histamine antagonism does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms such as tardive dyskinesia.

C) INCORRECT:

Some antipsychotics increase acetylcholine action in hippocampal pathways, which may explain suspected cognitive benefits. However, acetylcholine agonism does not contribute to extrapyramidal adverse effects such as tardive dyskinesia. Adverse effects of acetylcholine agonism include diarrhea, lacrimation, bradycardia, bronchoconstriction, and increased sweating.

D) INCORRECT:

Both fluphenazine and risperidone are dopamine antagonists without significant agonistic activity. Furthermore, dopamine antagonism, not agonism, is believed to be responsible for extrapyramidal adverse effects such as tardive dyskinesia.

E) CORRECT:

Both typical antipsychotics (e.g., fluphenazine) and atypical antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone) can be used to treat mania in bipolar disorder by antagonizing dopamine receptors in mesolimbic and mesocortical pathways. However, unintended dopamine antagonism in the nigrostriatal pathways can result in extrapyramidal adverse effects, such as tardive dyskinesia. Although both typical and atypical antipsychotics antagonize dopamine receptors, atypical antipsychotics have weaker interactions with D2 dopamine receptors, resulting in less dopamine antagonism and lower rates of extrapyramidal symptoms than typical antipsychotics.

F) INCORRECT:

Both atypical (e.g., risperidone) and typical (e.g., fluphenazine) antipsychotics do not have a significant agonistic action at histamine receptors. Further, histamine agonism does not contribute to extrapyramidal symptoms.

G) INCORRECT:

Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone) have stronger serotonin (5HT2A receptor) antagonism than typical antipsychotics (e.g., fluphenazine). This increased serotonin antagonism may improve cognition, but may also contribute to the metabolic adverse effects (hyperglycemia, weight gain, dyslipidemia) associated with atypical antipsychotics. Serotonin antagonism does not, however, cause extrapyramidal adverse effects such as tardive dyskinesia.
questions.hint: Lip smacking and choreoathetosis (dance-like movements) of the extremities in a patient who has been on a typical antipsychotic, like fluphenazine, is concerning for tardive dyskinesia. Risperidone, an atypical antipsychotic, has a different adverse effect profile.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of fever and productive cough for the past 4 days. During this period, he has had shortness of breath and chest pain that is worse on inspiration. He also reports fatigue and nausea. He has refractory schizophrenia and recurrent asthma attacks. He used to attend college but was expelled after threatening to harm one of his professors 2 months ago. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Crackles and bronchial breath sounds are heard on auscultation of the left lung. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
1,100/mm3


 Segmented neutrophils

5%


 Eosinophils
0%


 Lymphocytes
93%


 Monocytes
2%


Platelet count
260,000/mm3



Which of the following medications is this patient most likely taking?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Clozapine is used primarily for the treatment of refractory schizophrenia. While it is highly effective in the treatment of schizophrenia, it has serious adverse effects, which can include the life-threatening agranulocytosis (usually defined as an absolute neutrophil count < 500/mm3) seen in this patient. About 1–2% of all patients who begin taking clozapine eventually develop agranulocytosis (usually in the first months of treatment), though this risk falls substantially after the first year. The most common symptoms of agranulocytosis are oral ulcerations, fever, sore throat, malaise, and increased susceptibility to infections such as pneumonia. A complete blood count should be performed weekly for the first 6 months of treatment, every other week between 6 months and 1 year, and every 4 weeks after 1 year. Patients with mild agranulocytosis require more frequent screenings, while patients with severe agranulocytosis must discontinue the drug.

B) INCORRECT:

Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is commonly used as a first-line treatment for schizophrenia. Adverse effects include weight gain, hyperglycemia, and orthostatic hypotension, but it does not typically cause agranulocytosis. Furthermore, it is rarely used for refractory schizophrenia, making it an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Haloperidol is a high-potency antipsychotic that can cause extrapyramidal and anticholinergic adverse effects but it does not typically cause agranulocytosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic that can cause hyperprolactinemia, which may lead to gynecomastia; agranulocytosis is not a typical adverse effect.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlorpromazine is a medium-potency antipsychotic used for schizophrenia in addition to bipolar disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and nausea. It can cause extrapyramidal and anticholinergic symptoms, but this patient's agranulocytosis is not a typical adverse effect.

F) INCORRECT:

Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic that can cause sedation, metabolic syndrome, hyperglycemia, and weight gain. Agranulocytosis is not a typical adverse effect.
questions.hint: Other side effects of this drug include seizures (dose-dependent risk) and myocarditis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by his father because of altered mental status. According to the father, the patient was unable to get out of bed that morning and has become increasingly confused over the past several hours. The father also noticed it was “pretty cold” in his son's apartment because all of the windows were left open overnight. He has a history of hypothyroidism, schizoaffective disorder, type 2 diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, and hypertension. Ten days ago, he was started on a new medication. He appears lethargic. His rectal temperature is 32°C (89.6°F), pulse is 54/min, respirations are 8/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg. Examination shows weakness in the lower extremities with absent deep tendon reflexes. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the upper extremities. The pupils are dilated and poorly reactive to light. Throughout the examination, the patient attempts to remove his clothing. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril may be part of this patient's medication regimen for his hypertension. A potential side effect of ACE inhibitors is hyperkalemia, which can manifest with decreased deep tendon reflexes, as seen in this patient. However, hyperkalemia is not associated with hypothermia or mental status changes, and it would also manifest with muscle weakness, cardiac arrhythmias, and gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., constipation).

B) CORRECT:

Phenothiazines such as fluphenazine, which are used for maintenance therapy in patients with chronic psychotic disorders (e.g., schizoaffective disorder), cause impaired thermoregulation (i.e., hypothermia or hyperthermia), resulting in intolerance of extremes in environmental temperature. This side effect is believed to be due to the drug's effect on the hypothalamus, which leads to inappropriate responses to heat (e.g., lack of sweating/peripheral vasodilation) or cold (e.g., lack of shivering). Therefore, patients on fluphenazine therapy who are likely to be exposed to extreme temperatures (e.g., those who are homeless) should be closely monitored.

C) INCORRECT:

Tolbutamide, a first-generation sulfonylurea, may be part of this patient's medication regimen for his type 2 diabetes mellitus. One of its known side effects is a disulfiram-like reaction, which manifests with severe flushing, tachycardia, and hypotension. Tolbutamide is not associated with hypothermia.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's history of hypothyroidism predisposes him to myxedema coma, which classically manifests with altered mental status and hypothermia. Levothyroxine is likely to be part of this patient's medication regimen for his hypothyroidism. However, treatment with levothyroxine would rather prevent this patient from developing hypothermia due to hypothyroidism.

E) INCORRECT:

Atorvastatin may be part of this patient's medication regimen for his dyslipidemia. There is an association between the risk of statin myopathy and the risk of developing drug-induced malignant hyperthermia but statin use is not associated with hypothermia.
questions.hint: Altered mental status, decreased core body temperature, hyporeflexia, dilated pupils, and paradoxical removal of clothing in a patient who recently began a new drug indicates moderate hypothermia, which is an adverse effect of one of the following drugs.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician accompanied by her husband after he started noticing strange behavior. He first noticed her talking to herself 8 months ago. For the past 6 months, she has refused to eat any packaged foods out of fear that the government is trying to poison her. She has no significant past medical history. She smoked marijuana in college but has not smoked any since. She appears restless. Mental status examination shows a flat affect. Her speech is clear, but her thought process is disorganized with many loose associations. The patient is diagnosed with schizophrenia and started on olanzapine. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Olanzapine does not commonly cause seizures. In fact, it is one of the antipsychotics of choice for psychotic patients with a history of seizures. Clozapine is an antipsychotic that has a dose-dependent potential to reduce the seizure threshold and is, therefore, contraindicated in patients with seizure disorders.

B) INCORRECT:

Diabetes insipidus is more commonly seen with lithium therapy. Renal function parameters and serum electrolytes should be monitored in patients taking lithium. Diabetes mellitus (due to impaired metabolism) may occur with olanzapine therapy, but not diabetes insipidus.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism is not a known adverse effect of olanzapine therapy. It is more commonly seen with lithium therapy. Thyroid function tests should be performed every 6–12 months in patients taking lithium.

D) CORRECT:

Metabolic adverse effects (e.g., dyslipidemia, weight gain, hyperglycemia, new-onset diabetes mellitus) are very common adverse effects of olanzapine therapy. They may occur with other atypical antipsychotics as well but are most pronounced with olanzapine and clozapine (-apines). These adverse effects occur secondary to impairment of metabolism, most likely as a result of antagonism at H1 and 5-HT2 receptors in the CNS. Therefore, routine monitoring of BMI, waist circumference, fasting glucose, and fasting lipid levels is recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

As with other drugs that antagonize dopamine D2 receptors, olanzapine can elevate prolactin levels. Severe hyperprolactinemia leads to suppression of GnRH, resulting in decreased levels of LH and FSH, which can cause amenorrhea. The risk of severe hyperprolactinemia is highest with typical antipsychotics and certain atypical antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone). Severe hyperprolactinemia with resulting amenorrhea is not a common adverse effect of olanzapine therapy; other adverse effects are more common.

F) INCORRECT:

Agranulocytosis, a potential adverse effect of all antipsychotics, can lead to fatal infections. However, it is not a common adverse effect of olanzapine therapy. It is more frequently seen with clozapine. In contrast to clozapine therapy, which requires weekly complete blood counts during the first 6 months of treatment, complete blood counts are not routinely checked in patients taking olanzapine.

G) INCORRECT:

Myoglobinuria may occur in neuroleptic malignant syndrome, which is a rare adverse effect of olanzapine therapy. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is more often seen with administration of typical antipsychotics.
questions.hint: This particular adverse effect can also occur with thiazide diuretics, certain beta-blockers (e.g., metoprolol), and protease inhibitors.

questions.text: A 23-year old man is brought to the emergency department by his brother after trying to jump out of a moving car. He says that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been following him for the last 7 months. He recently quit his job at a local consulting firm to work on his mission to rid the world of evil. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He takes no medications. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/86 mm Hg. On mental status examination, his response to the first question lasts 5 minutes without interruption. He switches topics a number of times and his speech is pressured. He speaks excessively about his plan to “bring absolute justice to the world”. He has a labile affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. A toxicology screen is negative. He is admitted to the hospital and treatment is initiated. One week later, he develops difficulty walking and a tremor that improves with activity. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's motor symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cholinesterase inhibition is the mechanism of action for antidementia medications (e.g., donepezil). Considering the lack of memory dysfunction in this patient, cholinesterase inhibitors would not have been indicated, nor would they have caused EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

B) INCORRECT:

Direct GABA receptor agonists, such as barbiturates, and indirect GABA agonists like benzodiazepines, inhibit neuronal excitability and are used as sedatives. Although benzodiazepines may be considered as a chemical restraint for patients with psychosis exhibiting agitation, they are not used for patients without agitation nor would either drug group cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

C) INCORRECT:

Dopamine agonists, such as ropinirole and pramipexole, may be used in the treatment of Parkinson disease (especially during the early stages). This class of medication would not be given to patients with psychosis since they would further exacerbate psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations.
Image Description:

Dopamine agonists (e.g., ropinirole, bromocriptine) bind to the dopamine receptor, mimicking the action of dopamine.

DOPA-Decarboxylase (DDC) inhibitors (e.g., carbidopa) decrease the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, which results in reduced peripheral side-effects of L-DOPA. These drugs cannot cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore do not reduce dopamine production in the brain nor do they have central side-effects.

Dopamine precursors (e.g., L-DOPA) are converted by DOPA decarboxylase at the presynaptic neuron resulting in direct dopaminergic effects (especially in D2 receptors).

COMT inhibitors (e.g., entacapone, tolcapone) inhibits central (tolcapone) or peripheral (entacapone) catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) resulting in the reduced metabolization of dopamine, increase in dopamine effects, a decreased demand for L-DOPA, and a longer therapeutic effect with each dose.

MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) reduce the metabolism of central dopamine by inhibiting the monoamine oxidase B enzyme, which normally breaks down dopamine (and catecholamines) in the brain. This results in a prolonged dopamine effect and reduced demand for L-DOPA.

Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) inhibit excitatory cholinergic neurons, resulting in a proportionately lower concentration of acetylcholine compared to dopamine.

NMDA antagonists (e.g., amantadine) act as antagonists at the glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which results in a dopaminergic effect.

D) CORRECT:

Dopamine-2 receptor antagonism is the main mechanism of action for antipsychotics. All antipsychotics that interact with the D2 receptor can cause EPS, but this effect is particularly pronounced in the use of first-generation antipsychotics due to their high affinity to D2 receptors. Patients who have taken antipsychotics for days to weeks can develop features of pseudoparkinsonism, including tremors, rigidity, and shuffling gait. Antipsychotic-induced pseudoparkinsonism is managed by reducing the dose of the offending drug or switching to a second-generation antipsychotic. If dose reduction or switching is not possible, anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) or nonergot dopamine agonists (e.g., amantadine) can be used.

E) INCORRECT:

Anticholinergic agents (e.g., atropine, benztropine) cause the following side effects: confusion, agitation, hyperthermia, thirst, skin flushing, tachycardia, urinary retention, and dilated, nonreactive pupils. Anticholinergic agents would neither be indicated for the treatment of schizophrenia nor cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

F) INCORRECT:

Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) are used to treat major depressive disorder. They would neither be indicated for schizophrenia nor cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

G) INCORRECT:

Among other indications, first-generation H1 antihistamines are used as sedatives to treat insomnia, and second-generation antihistamines are used as antiallergic agents to treat rhinitis and hypersensitivity reactions. The side effects of first-generation H1 antihistamines include sedation and anticholinergic effects, such as dry mouth and eyes, mydriasis, dizziness, tinnitus, urinary retention, and tachycardia. However, they would neither be indicated for schizophrenia nor cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

H) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are first-line treatment for major depressive disorder. They can also be used to treat generalized anxiety disorder and obsessive compulsive disorder. However, they are neither routinely used for psychotic disorders, nor do they cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

I) INCORRECT:

Flumazenil is a GABAA receptor antagonist that is used in benzodiazepine overdose as it blocks the same binding site and reverses adverse effects such as confusion, impaired motor coordination, amnesia, drowsiness, and respiratory depression. It would neither be indicated for schizophrenia nor cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.
questions.hint: This patient presented with features of schizophrenia (delusions for at least 6 months, pressured and disorganized speech). The development of tremor and difficulty walking following initiation of treatment for schizophrenia are suggestive of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS).

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of increasing restlessness over the past 2 weeks. She reports that she continuously paces around the house and is unable to sit still for more than 10 minutes at a time. During this period, she has had multiple episodes of anxiety with chest tightness and shortness of breath. She was diagnosed with a psychotic illness 2 months ago. Her current medications include haloperidol and a multivitamin. She appears agitated. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The examination was interrupted multiple times when she became restless and began to walk around the room. To reduce the likelihood of the patient developing her current symptoms, a drug with which of the following mechanisms of action should have been prescribed instead of her current medication?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

H2 antagonists (e.g., cimetidine, famotidine) are used in the treatment of anaphylaxis, gastritis, peptic ulcer disease, and gastroesophageal reflux disease and are not associated with the development of akathisia.

Some low-potency, first-generation antipsychotics (e.g., chlorpromazine, thioridazine) also have antihistaminergic activity and cause fewer extrapyramidal adverse effects compared to high-potency antipsychotics (e.g. haloperidol), but this antagonistic activity occurs at H1 receptors, not H2 receptors. This activity is responsible for the sedative effects of these drugs.

B) INCORRECT:

NMDA receptor antagonists (e.g., ketamine, memantine) are not associated with the development of akathisia and are also not used in the treatment of psychotic illness. Instead, ketamine causes dissociative anesthesia (e.g., for rapid sequence intubation) and memantine is used to treat dementia due to Alzheimer disease.

C) INCORRECT:

GABA receptor antagonists (e.g., flumazenil) are not associated with the development of akathisia and are also not used to treat psychotic illnesses. Flumazenil is used to treat benzodiazepine overdose and can precipitate withdrawal seizures in patients with an extensive history of benzodiazepine use.

D) CORRECT:

Unlike first-generation antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol), second-generation antipsychotics (e.g., quetiapine, ziprasidone) exhibit antagonistic activity at 5-HT2A receptors, and, to a lesser degree, D3, α-adrenergic, and H1 receptors. In addition, second-generation antipsychotics are weaker D2 receptor antagonists than first-generation antipsychotics; as a result, these drugs cause fewer extrapyramidal adverse effects such as akathisia. Second-generation antipsychotics cause metabolic adverse effects such as weight gain, insulin resistance, and dyslipidemia more often than first-generation antipsychotics.

E) INCORRECT:

α2 receptor antagonists (e.g., mirtazapine) are not associated with the development of akathisia and are also not used to treat psychotic illnesses. Instead, mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant with adverse effects that include increased appetite, weight gain, and xerostomia.

F) INCORRECT:

Psychotic illnesses (e.g., schizophrenia) are most commonly caused by an imbalance of dopaminergic activity in the brain. Antipsychotic medications act primarily by blocking D2 receptors; D1 receptor antagonism is not a mechanism of action of this class of drug.
questions.hint: This patient has akathisia, a condition characterized by motor restlessness that is an adverse effect of treatment with first-generation antipsychotics such as haloperidol.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of increasing agitation and aggression at home. His mother thinks he has experimented with recreational drugs in the past. He appears acutely agitated and attempts to hit multiple medical staff members. Haloperidol is administered and the patient is admitted. The next morning, the patient reports worsening neck pain. He states that his neck is locked to the left and he cannot move it. He is currently alert and oriented. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/75 mm Hg. Examination shows rigidity of his upper body and neck, with the neck fixed in flexion and rotated to the left. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propranolol can help treat akathisia, which is also a type of EPS. Instead of the restlessness that is characteristic of akathisia, this patient presents with muscle spasms indicative of acute dystonic reaction, for which propranolol has no benefit.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute dystonic reactions are thought to be caused by an imbalance between decreased dopaminergic signaling (due to antipsychotic medication) and increased cholinergic signaling (due to downregulated dopamine). Administration of physostigmine would upregulate acetylcholine and could potentially exacerbate this patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Although benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam) can be used as a treatment for acute dystonic reaction, it is a second-line therapy and is only to be given if the appropriate first-line agents are ineffective.

D) INCORRECT:

Clozapine may be indicated for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and in some patients with EPS (especially those who develop tardive dyskinesia) because of clozapine's low risk for development of EPS. However, clozapine should be initiated cautiously due to the risk of severe side effects, like agranulocytosis. In this patient with acute dystonic reaction from haloperidol use in the acute setting, clozapine would have no benefit.

E) INCORRECT:

Injection of botulinum toxin into a particular muscle group is a treatment option for muscle spasms in acute dystonic reaction that are refractory to other therapeutic options. However, botulinum toxin is not the most appropriate first-line therapy in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Acute dystonic reactions are thought to occur as a result of an imbalance between decreased dopaminergic signaling (due to the antipsychotic medication) and increased cholinergic signaling (due to downregulated dopamine). The first-line treatment for acute dystonic reactions is a drug with anticholinergic activity (e.g., benztropine, diphenhydramine). Care should also be taken to avoid antipsychotics with a high propensity for EPS. Patients who receive haloperidol may also benefit from prophylactic treatment with benztropine to prevent acute dystonic reactions.

Acute dystonic reactions can also affect the extraocular muscles (oculogyric crisis) and laryngeal muscles (causing life-threatening laryngospasm).

G) INCORRECT:

Bromocriptine, an ergot dopamine receptor agonist, is indicated for the treatment of neuroleptic malignant syndrome, which can occur soon after initiating a high-potency antipsychotic medication but typically also manifests with features of autonomic instability (e.g., hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis), altered mental status, tremors, and diffuse rather than localized muscle rigidity. Bromocriptine is not indicated for the treatment of acute dystonic reactions.
questions.hint: Muscle spasms (e.g., torticollis) occurring hours to days following antipsychotic use (especially high-potency first-generation antipsychotics such as haloperidol) are suggestive of an acute dystonic reaction, a type of extrapyramidal symptom (EPS).

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Three weeks ago, he was diagnosed with schizophrenia and treatment with trifluoperazine and cognitive behavioral therapy was initiated. He reports feeling better since starting treatment but says that he has recently developed difficulty with daily tasks, such as typing and picking up the phone. He works as an administrative assistant. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. He drinks two beers daily and does not use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows rigidity and shuffling gait. On mental status examination, his speech is normal, and his thought processes are linear with no disturbances of thought content or suicidal ideation. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. After discontinuing trifluoperazine, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy at this time?

choices.text: No pharmacotherapy is necessary at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clozapine is a very effective second-generation antipsychotic but is only used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia (i.e., persistent symptoms despite taking 2 different antipsychotics at their maximum doses for ≥ 6 weeks) because of the risk for significant side effects (e.g., agranulocytosis).

B) CORRECT:

The choice of antipsychotic for the treatment of schizophrenia depends on the patient's profile and preferences; either an FGA or a second-generation antipsychotic (SGA) can be used. Because this patient developed extrapyramidal symptoms due to treatment with an FGA, the drug should be discontinued and treatment should be replaced by an SGA such as quetiapine. In contrast to FGAs, SGAs carry a lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms and hyperprolactinemia. SGAs, especially olanzapine and clozapine, have an increased risk of metabolic side effects (e.g., weight gain, hyperglycemia).

Patients with schizophrenia typically require lifelong antipsychotic therapy even if there is an adequate response to initial treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Paliperidone is a second-generation antipsychotic that can be used to treat schizophrenia. For maintenance therapy in schizophrenia, an intramuscular injection of a depot preparation of an antipsychotic is only considered if the patient has poor medication adherence to daily oral antipsychotic medication. This patient has no history of medication nonadherence.

An intramuscular antipsychotic injection is also used for the acute management of psychosis if the patient is severely agitated. This patient is calm and not in a psychotic state.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral amantadine is a dopamine agonist used to treat pseudoparkinsonism in patients taking antipsychotic drugs. However, it is only indicated if pseudoparkinsonism persists after stopping the causative drug.

E) INCORRECT:

Haloperidol is a high-potency FGA that can be used to treat schizophrenia. However, this patient has previously developed extrapyramidal symptoms with an FGA. Therefore, a different treatment option should be considered.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizophrenia typically require lifelong antipsychotic therapy even if there is an adequate response to initial treatment. Discontinuing antipsychotic therapy puts the patient at risk of relapse.
questions.hint: This patient with schizophrenia developed extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g., pseudoparkinsonism) following treatment with trifluoperazine, a first-generation antipsychotic (FGA).

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being detained by campus police for attempting to steal from the bookstore. Her roommate says that the patient has been acting strangely over the last 2 weeks. She has not slept in 4 days and has painted her room twice in that time span. She has also spent all of her savings on online shopping and lottery tickets. She has no history of psychiatric illness or substance abuse, and takes no medications. During the examination, she is uncooperative, combative, and refusing care. She screams, “Let me go, God has a plan for me and I must go finish it!”. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she describes her mood as “amazing.” She has a labile affect, speaks rapidly, and her thought process is tangential. She denies having any hallucinations. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clozapine, an antipsychotic, is used for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. Because of its potential adverse effect of agranulocytosis, it is reserved as maintenance therapy in patients with refractory schizophrenia and requires close monitoring. It is not used for treatment of bipolar disorder or acute mania.

B) INCORRECT:

Venlafaxine, a selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), is commonly used in the treatment of major depressive disorder, anxiety, and panic disorder. It can actually worsen or trigger manic episodes, and should not be used in patients with a history of mania.

C) CORRECT:

Antipsychotics, e.g., haloperidol or risperidone, are the preferred initial treatment for an agitated and combative patient with acute mania. Their rapid onset and the possibility of intramuscular administration will allow for rapid sedation. A mood stabilizer should eventually be initiated and titrated for long-term maintenance therapy, but this will take a few days to take effect and she is in need of rapid stabilization at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Lithium, a mood stabilizer, is a first-line treatment option for bipolar affective disorder. It is effective in preventing both manic episodes and depression in bipolar patients when employed for long-term maintenance therapy. However, its oral route of administration, slower onset, and need for gradual titration makes it less useful as an initial therapy in an agitated patient with an acute manic episode.

E) INCORRECT:

Valproate, an anticonvulsant, is commonly used to treat bipolar disorder. Its mood-stabilizing effects make it a first-line choice for long-term maintenance treatment following an acute manic episode. However, its oral route of administration, slower onset, and need for gradual titration makes it less useful as an initial therapy in an agitated patient with an acute manic episode.

F) INCORRECT:

Sertraline, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), would be an appropriate initial treatment for major depressive disorder or anxiety, but is actually contraindicated for acute mania. In an acutely manic patient, any current antidepressants should be immediately discontinued as they may contribute to the manic episode.
questions.hint: This patient's history of elevated mood, reckless behavior, insomnia, pressured speech, and psychosis is consistent with an acute manic episode. Her uncooperative and combative behavior (severe agitation) will influence our choice of initial therapy.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 26-year-old man comes to the physician for medication counseling after recently being diagnosed with schizophrenia. Risperidone therapy is initiated. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Agranulocytosis is a potentially life-threatening side effect of clozapine, which, like risperidone, is an atypical antipsychotic. However, risperidone rarely causes agranulocytosis (< 1%).

B) INCORRECT:

A shortened QT interval can occur secondary to electrolyte disorders and drug effects (e.g., digoxin), but it is not a side effect of atypical antipsychotics, such as risperidone. Instead, atypical antipsychotics cause prolongation of the QT interval.

C) CORRECT:

Risperidone acts as a D2 receptor antagonist, thereby disrupting the inhibitory effect of dopamine within the tuberoinfundibular pathway. The subsequent increase in prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary gland causes hyperprolactinemia, which stimulates the proliferation of the mammary gland. Patients subsequently develop gynecomastia and galactorrhea. Hyperprolactinemia also inhibits the release of GnRH from the hypothalamus, causing hypogonadotropic hypogonadism; this manifests in males with sexual dysfunction (erectile dysfunction, infertility).

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism is a potential side effect of lithium, which is an antimanic drug used in the treatment of bipolar affective disorder. Risperidone and other atypical antipsychotics do not affect thyroid function.

E) INCORRECT:

Risperidone and other atypical antipsychotics are associated with metabolic side effects, including hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, and weight gain. Weight loss is not a typical side effect.
questions.hint: Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic with high affinity for dopamine D2 receptors.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a 6-month history of irregular menstrual periods. Her last period was 3 months ago. Previously, her periods occurred at regular 28-day intervals and lasted 4–5 days with moderate flow. She has also noticed breast tenderness and scant nipple discharge. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and refractory bipolar I disorder. Current medications include metformin, glipizide, lithium, and risperidone. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the changes in her menstrual cycle?

choices.text: Dysregulation of theca and granulosa cell steroidogenesis
Impaired production and release of thyroxine
Failure of ovaries to respond to gonadotropins

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dysregulation of theca and granulosa cell steroidogenesis is seen in polycystic ovarian syndrome, which can cause menstrual cycle irregularities, as seen in this patient. PCOS should also be considered in patients with diabetes mellitus, such as this woman, as insulin resistance plays a key role in the pathophysiology of both PCOS and diabetes mellitus. However, this woman lacks other typical clinical features of PCOS, including signs of hyperandrogenism and virilization (e.g., hirsutism and acne vulgaris). Finally, PCOS would not explain this patient's nipple discharge.
Image Description:

In polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), peripheral insulin resistance (e.g., due to obesity) causes hyperinsulinemia. Hyperinsulinemia stimulates androgen production in cells of the ovarian theca interna. Levels of free androgens are further increased by reduced sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) production in the liver. Hyperandrogenemia stimulates LH release from the anterior pituitary gland, resulting in a disruption of LH/FSH balance and, consequently, impaired follicle maturation. LH/FSH balance is further impaired by increased GnRH pulsatility in the hypothalamus and the conversion of androgens to estrogen in adipose tissue.

B) INCORRECT:

Reduced renal elimination of prolactin can cause hyperprolactinemia in patients with chronic renal failure due to reduced renal elimination of prolactin. However, this patient has no evidence of renal failure (e.g., hypertension, edema, features of uremia).

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired production and release of thyroxine are seen in hypothyroidism. An increase in TRH stimulates prolactin secretion causing hyperprolactinemia and its associated symptoms, such as oligomenorrhea and nipple discharge. Hypothyroidism is also a side effect of lithium, which this patient takes. However, this woman lacks other signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain, constipation), making another cause more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Failure of the ovaries to respond to gonadotropins occurs in ovarian failure, which may present with menopause. Although this patient has amenorrhea, she lacks other characteristic features of menopause, such as sweating, hot flashes, and mood swings. Furthermore, ovarian failure would not explain her nipple discharge.

E) CORRECT:

Blockade of pituitary dopamine receptors is likely to have caused this patient's hyperprolactinemia. Dopamine secreted by the hypothalamus normally inhibits the secretion of prolactin from the anterior pituitary. Although typical antipsychotics are most commonly associated with this side effect, atypical antipsychotics, especially risperidone, can also cause hyperprolactinemia. Risperidone antagonizes D2 dopaminergic receptors, decreasing dopamine's tonic inhibition of prolactin secretion and resulting in hyperprolactinemia. Prolactin acts directly on breast epithelial cells to stimulate milk production (hence this patient's galactorrhea). Because prolactin inhibits GnRH secretion, hyperprolactinemia can also result in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (hence this patient's amenorrhea).
Image Description:

The nontropic releasing hormones are released in the hypothalamus (A) to the portal vascular system of the anterior pituitary gland (adenohypophysis , 2), where the nontropic hormones growth hormone (GH), melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH), and prolactin are released (2). These trigger the secretion of hormones in the target organs: GH leads to the secretion of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) in the liver, which has an anabolic effect on the muscles and bones (3). In the skin, MSH stimulates the production of melanocytes (4). Prolactin triggers growth and lactation in the mammary glands (5). The inhibiting hormones are also released in the hypothalamus and subsequently reach the anterior pituitary gland, where they inhibit the release of nontropic hormones.

(GHRH = growth hormone-releasing hormone, TRH = thyrotropin-releasing hormone, MSH-RH = melanocyte-stimulating hormone-releasing hormone, MSH-IH = melanocyte-stimulating hormone-inhibiting hormone, Dop = dopamine)
questions.hint: This patient's history of menstrual irregularities and nipple discharge are suggestive of hyperprolactinemia.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man with schizophrenia comes to the physician because of erectile dysfunction for the past month. He cannot maintain an erection during intercourse and rarely wakes up with an erection. He says he is happy in his current relationship, but admits to decreased desire for sex and feeling embarrassed about his sexual performance. He sustained a lumbar vertebral injury one year ago following a motor vehicle accident. He takes medication for his schizophrenia but does not remember the name. Physical examination shows testicular atrophy with otherwise normal genitalia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Atypical antipsychotics can cause erectile dysfunction and hypogonadism due to their effects as dopamine antagonists and subsequent disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. Dopamine antagonists stimulate prolactin secretion, which leads to the downstream effects of decreased GnRH secretion from the hypothalamus, decreased LH secretion from the anterior pituitary, and decreased production of testosterone by Leydig cells in the testes. This results in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which would explain this patient's erectile dysfunction, decreased libido, and testicular atrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Peyronie disease is a fibroproliferative disorder affecting the tunica albuginea of the penis. Patients typically present with penile pain, curving of the penis during an erection, and/or palpable nodules and induration of the penis. This patient has no signs or symptoms of Peyronie disease and his testicular atrophy suggests a different cause of his sexual dysfunction.
Image Description:

Photograph of an erect penis showing an abnormal downward curvature.

C) INCORRECT:

Microvascular disease is a very common cause of erectile dysfunction in patients with cardiovascular risk factors, such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and/or smoking history. Microvascular disease causes endothelial dysfunction and decreased levels of nitric oxide, thereby impairing vasodilation of vessels supplying the corpus cavernosum. However, this patient lacks cardiovascular risk factors and presents with testicular atrophy, which would not be explained by microvascular disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Afferent fibers from the pudendal nerve transmit sensory stimuli from the external genitalia and perineum to the parasympathetic nervous system, where efferent signals are generated to mediate an erection. Damage to peripheral nerves can interfere with this neural pathway and lead to neurogenic causes of erectile dysfunction. This patient has no symptoms of neurologic disorders and presents with testicular atrophy, which would not be explained by peripheral nerve injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Psychologic stressors (e.g., depression, previous traumatic experiences, relationship trouble) are common causes of erectile dysfunction. Patients with psychogenic erectile dysfunction usually get morning erections, but have difficulty getting or maintaining erections during intercourse with a partner. This patient rarely has morning erections and presents with testicular atrophy, making psychologic stressors an unlikely primary cause for his sexual dysfunction.
questions.hint: This patient with schizophrenia is likely being treated with an atypical antipsychotic. These medications can cause hyperprolactinemia, leading to sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of repetitive tongue twisting and abnormal movements of the hands and legs that started several days ago. She has a 2-year history of schizophrenia that has been controlled with fluphenazine. Two weeks ago, she was switched to risperidone. Examination shows protrusion of the tongue and smacking of the lips. She makes twisting movements of the arms and frequently taps her right foot. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tourette syndrome is a tic disorder characterized by rapid, involuntary motor and vocal tics that occur several times daily on most days. It is not associated with antipsychotic drug treatment, but with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and obsessive-compulsive disorder. Onset is typically before the age of 18.

B) INCORRECT:

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a life-threatening condition that usually appears within the first 2 weeks of treatment with antipsychotic medications (most often typical antipsychotics). Repetitive involuntary movements would not be seen in NMS. Instead, NMS is characterized by hyperthermia, muscular rigidity, autonomic instability, and mental status change.

C) INCORRECT:

Akathisia is the most common form of neuroleptic-induced extrapyramidal symptoms, usually manifesting within a few weeks of treatment and manifesting with restlessness and a compelling urge to move. While constant movements, as seen in this patient, may occur, they are not entirely involuntary, repetitive, or purposeless and are more a result of an inability to sit still.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute dystonia typically presents within hours to days after the intake of antipsychotics and manifests with painful and lasting muscle spasms that predominantly affect the head, neck (torticollis), and tongue. Unlike in this patient, movements are nonrepetitive and affect a single muscle group.

E) CORRECT:

Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is a neuroleptic-induced extrapyramidal symptom (EPS) that usually manifests months to years after the initiation of maintenance antipsychotic therapy with purposeless, repetitive, involuntary orofacial and extremity movements often with a choreiform and/or athetotic characteristic (e.g., lip smacking, twisting movements of the arms). As with other forms of EPS, TD generally occurs more frequently in conjunction with typical antipsychotics (e.g., fluphenazine), which this patient has received for 2 years, and to a lesser extent with atypical antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone). Cross-tapering to clozapine or quetiapine, which have a very low risk of EPS, should be considered for patients with TD but TD can be irreversible and persist even after discontinuation of the offending drug. Vesicular monoamine transporter-2 inhibitors (e.g., valbenazine, deutetrabenazine) can be used to treat moderate to severe TD.

See “Overview of extrapyramidal symptoms” table.

F) INCORRECT:

Pseudoparkinsonism usually develops days to weeks after initiating therapy with an antipsychotic drug and manifests with the classic symptoms of parkinsonism (e.g., cogwheel rigidity, stiff gait, tremor). Repetitive choreiform or athetotic movements as seen in this patient would not be present.
questions.hint: It is common for this condition to first appear after initiating treatment with an anticholinergic drug, reduction in antipsychotic medication dose, or, as in this case, changing to a less potent antipsychotic medication due to an unmasking effect.

questions.text: Two weeks after hospitalization for acute psychosis, a 27-year-old woman with a history of paranoid schizophrenia comes to the physician because of difficulty walking and shaking movements of her hands. Current medications include fluphenazine, which was started during her recent hospitalization. Examination shows a shuffling gait, rigidity in the upper extremities, and a low-amplitude tremor of her hands that improves with activity. Mental status examination shows no abnormalities. Treatment with a drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is most likely to provide relief for this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

β-adrenergic antagonists such as propranolol are the preferred treatment for essential tremor. Unlike this patient's tremor, essential tremor typically manifests as a bilateral tremor of the hands that worsens with voluntary movements but resolves at rest. Moreover, essential tremors are sporadic or hereditary in nature and are not associated with consumption of antipsychotic drugs.

β-adrenergic antagonists are also used as first-line treatment for akathisia, the most common form of extrapyramidal syndrome (EPS) caused by high-potency typical antipsychotic use.

B) INCORRECT:

GABA agonists, such as benzodiazepines, are not indicated for drug-induced pseudoparkinsonism but are used as a second-line treatment for drug-induced acute dystonia (second-line due to its anticholinergic properties). This extrapyramidal symptom (EPS) manifests within hours to days of antipsychotic treatment with painful and lasting muscle spasms of the eye, tongue, neck (torticollis), and back muscles. After acute treatment of the dystonia, the offending antipsychotic drug should be replaced with an antipsychotic that has a lower risk for EPS.

Benzodiazepines are also used as alternative agents in the treatment of akathisia.

C) INCORRECT:

Immediate discontinuation of the offending antipsychotic drug and replacement with the weak dopamine antagonist clozapine is recommended in patients who develop signs of tardive dyskinesia. This extrapyramidal symptom (EPS) involves involuntary choreoathetoid movements of the mouth (repetitive chewing and lip-smacking), face, and extremities, which develop after months to years of treatment. Although switching to an atypical antipsychotic drug generally reduces the risk of EPS progression, another drug is more likely to provide immediate relief for this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

D) INCORRECT:

The histamine antagonist diphenhydramine is not indicated for drug-induced pseudoparkinsonism but is used as a second-line treatment for drug-induced acute dystonia (second-line due to its anticholinergic properties). Acute dystonia manifests within hours to days of antipsychotic treatment with painful and lasting spasms of the eye, tongue, neck (torticollis), and back muscles. After acute treatment of the dystonia, the offending antipsychotic drug should be replaced with an antipsychotic with a lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

Antipsychotic-induced pseudoparkinsonism is generally treated with dose reduction or discontinuation of the offending drug. However, if this does not suffice or is not feasible due to active psychotic illness, pharmaceutical treatment should be initiated to provide symptomatic relief. Centrally-acting muscarinic antagonists, e.g., benztropine and trihexyphenidyl, are the preferred treatment for pseudoparkinsonism associated with antipsychotic drugs in most patients. Elderly patients, however, should be treated with amantadine to avoid the potential anticholinergic side effects of muscarinic antagonists (e.g., dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention, cognitive impairments, delirium).
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of Parkinson disease (bradykinesia, muscle rigidity, resting tremor) after several weeks of treatment with high-potency typical antipsychotics. This suggests antipsychotic-induced pseudoparkinsonism.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman with schizophrenia comes to the office for a follow-up appointment. She has been hospitalized 4 times in the past year, and she has failed to respond to multiple trials of antipsychotic medications. Six weeks ago, she was brought to the emergency department by her husband because of bizarre behavior, paranoid delusions, and hearing voices that others did not hear. She was started on a new medication, and her symptoms have improved. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.8 g/dL


Leukocyte count
1,200/mm3



Segmented neutrophils
6%


Eosinophils
0%


Lymphocytes
92%


Monocytes
2%


Platelet count
245,000/mm3



This patient was most likely started on which of the following medications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluphenazine is a high-potency antipsychotic that can cause extrapyramidal and anticholinergic adverse effects, neither of which are seen in this patient. This patient's agranulocytosis is not an expected adverse effect.

B) INCORRECT:

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic that can cause hyperprolactinemia, which may lead to gynecomastia. This patient's agranulocytosis is not a typical adverse effect.

C) INCORRECT:

Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is commonly used as first-line treatment for schizophrenia. Adverse effects include weight gain, hyperglycemia, and orthostatic hypotension, but it does not typically cause agranulocytosis. Furthermore, it is rarely used for refractory schizophrenia, making it an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic that can cause sedation, metabolic syndrome, hyperglycemia, and weight gain. This patient's agranulocytosis is not a typical adverse effect.

E) INCORRECT:

Promethazine is a low-potency antipsychotic that can cause extrapyramidal and anticholinergic adverse effects, neither of which are seen in this patient. This patient's agranulocytosis is not an expected adverse effect.

F) INCORRECT:

Chlorpromazine is a medium-potency antipsychotic used for schizophrenia in addition to bipolar disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and nausea. It can cause extrapyramidal and anticholinergic symptoms, but this patient's agranulocytosis is not a typical adverse effect.

G) INCORRECT:

Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorder and can cause hypothyroidism, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, and fine tremors, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, lithium is not used in the management of treatment-resistant schizophrenia and would not explain this patient's agranulocytosis.

H) CORRECT:

Clozapine is used primarily for schizophrenia resistant to first-line pharmacological therapy. While it is highly effective in the treatment of schizophrenia, it has serious adverse effects, which can include the life-threatening agranulocytosis seen in this patient. About 1–2% of all patients who begin taking clozapine eventually develop agranulocytosis (usually in the first months of treatment), though this risk falls substantially after the first year. The most common symptoms of agranulocytosis are oral ulcerations, sore throat, fever, malaise, and increased susceptibility to infections such as pneumonia.
questions.hint: This patient has treatment-resistant schizophrenia (failure to respond to multiple trials of antipsychotic medications). She was most likely started on the gold standard antipsychotic for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. The patient's laboratory studies show neutropenia, which should raise concern for agranulocytosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because she has appeared increasingly agitated over the last week. She feels restless, has not been able to sleep well, and has been pacing around her house continuously in an attempt to relieve her symptoms. Two weeks ago, she was diagnosed with schizophrenia and treatment with fluphenazine was initiated. Today, physical examination is interrupted multiple times because she is unable to sit or stand still for more than a couple minutes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In restless legs syndrome (RLS), patients experience disturbed sleep caused by an urge to move, similar to this patient. However, in RLS, movement typically relieves the urge to move, whereas this patient does not find relief. This patient also has symptoms during the day as well as at night, whereas the symptoms of RLS have a circadian rhythm. Restless legs syndrome is not associated with antipsychotic medications.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudoparkinsonism, a subtype of EPS, can be induced by antipsychotic drugs and it appears within days to weeks of treatment initiation. However, pseudoparkinsonism is characterized by tremors, cogwheel rigidity, and a shuffling gait.

C) INCORRECT:

Athetosis may occur as a feature of tardive dyskinesia, which can occur as an EPS following months to years of exposure to antipsychotic drugs. However, this patient has only been taking fluphenazine for 2 weeks. Furthermore, athetosis is characterized by slow, continuous, involuntary writhing movements, which are not present here.

D) CORRECT:

Akathisia describes the symptoms of motor restlessness seen here. It is an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic medications, especially high-potency typical antipsychotics (e.g., fluphenazine). The onset of akathisia is typically within 1–8 weeks of treatment initiation, as seen here. If feasible, this patient should have her fluphenazine dosage reduced or she should be switched to an antipsychotic drug with a lower risk of EPS. For persistent akathisia, the first-line pharmacotherapy is a beta blocker (e.g., propranolol). Benzodiazepine or benztropine therapy can be considered for akathisia refractory to beta blocker therapy.

Other important forms of EPS are pseudoparkinsonism, acute dystonic reactions, and tardive dyskinesia. Pseudoparkinsonism occurs within the same timeframe as akathisia but is characterized by tremors, cogwheel rigidity, and a shuffling gait. Acute dystonic reactions occur more immediately (within hours to days), and tardive dyskinesia occurs later (months to years).

See “Overview of extrapyramidal symptoms” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Schizophrenia can cause agitation due to distressing delusions or hallucinations. This patient does not report changes in her thoughts or perceptions but instead seems agitated by her own restlessness and inability to remain still.

F) INCORRECT:

Tardive dyskinesia is a potentially irreversible and disabling side effect of prolonged exposure (months to years) to dopamine receptor antagonists such as antipsychotics and certain antiemetics. It is a subtype of EPS and involves motor symptoms. However, this patient has only been taking fluphenazine for 2 weeks. Furthermore, the most common manifestations of tardive dyskinesia are purposeless, repetitive, involuntary orofacial and extremity movements often with a choreiform and/or athetotic characteristic.

G) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced mania can be caused by medications such as stimulants and corticosteroids, and antidepressant medications can induce hypomania or mania in patients with bipolar disorder. This patient's restlessness, poor sleep, and anxiety would fit with the diagnosis of drug-induced mania, but she is not taking antidepressants, corticosteroids, or stimulants. Mania is not a typical side effect of antipsychotics and is not a subtype of EPS.
questions.hint: This patient has escalating agitation, restlessness, poor sleep, continuous pacing, and the inability to remain still for more than a few minutes. She likely has the most common subtype of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS).

questions.text:
The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set.
For each patient treated with an antipsychotic medication, select the most likely diagnosis.
A) Tardive dyskinesia
B) Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
C) Akathisia
D) Acute dystonia
E) Pseudoparkinsonism
F) Tourette syndrome
G) Serotonin syndrome
H) Huntington disease
I) Restless legs syndrome
A 60-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of involuntary movements of the tongue and face that started 2 days ago. She has schizophrenia that has been controlled with haloperidol decanoate for the past 18 months. She lives in an assisted-living facility. She does not drink alcohol but has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 138/75 mm Hg. Examination shows protrusion of the tongue and slow, rhythmic perioral movements. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Treatment with benztropine is begun. One week later, her symptoms have worsened.
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is a movement disorder characterized by involuntary movements of the tongue and mouth, as seen in this patient, that manifest within months to years following the administration of dopamine-blocking agents. The annual risk of developing TD from first-generation antipsychotic use is up to 25% among older adults while the annual risk associated with second-generation antipsychotic use is ∼ 5%. Symptoms often persist despite discontinuation of the offending drug. Vesicular monoamine transporter-2 inhibitors (e.g., valbenazine, deutetrabenazine) can be used to treat moderate to severe TD. Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) can exacerbate symptoms, as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a life-threatening condition that can develop within the first 2 weeks following the administration of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as haloperidol). This condition is characterized by hyperthermia, muscular rigidity, autonomic instability, and mental status changes; it does not cause involuntary movements of the tongue and face.

C) INCORRECT:

Akathisia is a movement disorder that can manifest following the administration of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as haloperidol). However, it usually develops within the first 1–8 weeks after initiation of therapy. In addition, this condition is characterized by motor restlessness (i.e., a compelling urge to move), which can manifest with an inability to sit or stand still; it does not cause involuntary movements of the tongue and face. Moreover, this condition typically improves with benztropine therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute dystonia is an adverse effect of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as haloperidol) that can manifest with protrusion of the tongue. However, this adverse effect usually manifests within hours to days after initiation of therapy. In addition, it typically also causes painful, lasting muscle spasms that most commonly affect the head and neck, which this patient does not have. Moreover, acute dystonia typically improves with benztropine therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Pseudoparkinsonism can develop days to weeks following the administration of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as haloperidol). This condition typically manifests with the classic symptoms of parkinsonism (e.g., cogwheel rigidity, stiff gait, tremor); it does not cause involuntary movements of the tongue and face. In addition, this condition typically improves with benztropine therapy.

F) INCORRECT:

Tourette syndrome is a movement disorder characterized by involuntary vocal and motor tics. Patients with this condition can develop involuntary movements of the tongue and face. However, Tourette syndrome typically manifests during childhood. This patient's age and history of chronic use of a first-generation antipsychotic indicate another diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Serotonin syndrome is a life-threatening condition that most commonly develops due to concurrent use of ≥ 2 serotonergic drugs. It classically manifests with autonomic dysfunction (e.g., diaphoresis, fever), altered mental status (e.g., confusion, agitation, anxiety), and neuromuscular excitability (e,g., hypertonia, myoclonus, tremor), none of which are seen in this patient. In addition, this patient does not take a serotonergic medication.

H) INCORRECT:

Huntington disease is a neurologic disorder that can manifest with choreiform movements of the face. However, symptoms of this condition typically develop in the fourth or fifth decade of life. In addition, this patient does not have other typical features of Huntington disease, including hyperreflexia, sensory deficits, and autonomic disturbances. This patient's history of chronic use of a first-generation antipsychotic indicates another diagnosis.

I) INCORRECT:

Restless legs syndrome is a neurologic sleep disorder characterized by abnormal, nonpainful sensations in the legs and an irresistible urge to move them, especially during periods of rest. This condition is not associated with involuntary movements of the tongue and face.
questions.hint: This patient's current condition is often irreversible.

questions.text:
For each patient treated with an antipsychotic medication, select the most likely diagnosis.
A) Tardive dyskinesia
B) Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
C) Akathisia
D) Acute dystonia
E) Pseudoparkinsonism
F) Tourette syndrome
G) Serotonin syndrome
H) Huntington disease
I) Restless legs syndrome
A 30-year-old man is brought to the physician by his husband because of difficulty walking over the past 7 days. He reports feeling stiffness in the legs and has difficulty standing from a seated position. He has bipolar I disorder treated with lithium carbonate. He has been hospitalized 5 times over the past 8 months for acute manic episodes. During his last hospitalization 10 days ago, fluphenazine therapy was initiated. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/73 mm Hg. Physical examination shows increased resistance to passive movement of the joints in the lower extremities. The patient takes short, quick steps during ambulation and has difficulty maintaining his balance while standing. Gentle tapping between the eyebrows causes the patient to close his eyes.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tardive dyskinesia is a movement disorder that can manifest within months to years following the administration of dopamine-blocking agents (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as fluphenazine). It most commonly causes involuntary movements of the tongue and mouth (e.g., lip-smacking, repetitive chewing); it does not manifest with limb rigidity, shuffling gait, postural instability, or an unhabituated glabellar reflex.

B) INCORRECT:

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a life-threatening condition that can develop within the first 2 weeks following the administration of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as fluphenazine). This condition causes muscular rigidity, but it does not cause a shuffling gait, postural instability, or an unhabituated glabellar reflex. In addition, this patient lacks other typical characteristics of NMS, including hyperthermia, autonomic instability, and altered mental status.

C) INCORRECT:

Akathisia is a movement disorder that can manifest within 1–8 weeks following the administration of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as fluphenazine). This condition is characterized by motor restlessness (i.e., a compelling urge to move), which can manifest with an inability to sit or stand still; it does not manifest with limb rigidity, shuffling gait, postural instability, or an unhabituated glabellar reflex.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute dystonia is an adverse effect of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as fluphenazine) that can manifest within hours to days after initiation of therapy. This condition typically causes painful, lasting muscle spasms that most commonly affect the head, neck, and tongue, which this patient does not have. Acute dystonia does not manifest with limb rigidity, shuffling gait, postural instability, or an unhabituated glabellar reflex.

E) CORRECT:

Pseudoparkinsonism is a drug-induced movement disorder that can develop days to weeks after the initiation of dopamine-blocking agents (e.g., first-generation antipsychotics). This condition manifests with symptoms of parkinsonism, such as limb rigidity, shuffling gait, bradykinesia, postural instability, and an unhabituated glabellar reflex, all of which are seen in this patient. Lithium therapy is also associated with pseudoparkinsonism; the combination of lithium and fluphenazine therapy increased this patient's risk of developing this condition. Other medications associated with pseudoparkinsonism include metoclopramide and valproate.

F) INCORRECT:

Tourette syndrome is a movement disorder characterized by involuntary vocal and motor tics. It does not manifest with limb rigidity, shuffling gait, postural instability, or an unhabituated glabellar reflex. Moreover, Tourette syndrome typically manifests during childhood.

G) INCORRECT:

Serotonin syndrome is a life-threatening condition that most commonly develops due to concurrent use of ≥ 2 serotonergic drugs. It classically manifests with autonomic dysfunction (e.g., diaphoresis, fever), altered mental status (e.g., confusion, agitation, anxiety), and neuromuscular excitability (e,g., hypertonia, myoclonus, tremor), none of which are seen in this patient. In addition, this patient does not take a serotonergic medication.

H) INCORRECT:

Huntington disease is a neurologic disorder that typically manifests with choreiform movements, cognitive decline, behavioral changes, hyperreflexia, sensory deficits, and autonomic disturbances in the fourth or fifth decade of life. This patient does not show these features. Moreover, Huntington disease does not manifest with limb rigidity, shuffling gait, postural instability, or an unhabituated glabellar reflex.

I) INCORRECT:

Restless legs syndrome is a neurologic sleep disorder characterized by abnormal, nonpainful sensations in the legs and an irresistible urge to move them, especially during periods of rest.
